simple_results: [{"detection_name": "Introspection Enabled", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Information Disclosure", "description": "GraphQL introspection enabled - potential information disclosure", "evidence": "Found __schema in response data - introspection queries are allowed"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: Introspection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL endpoint returns full introspection results (the __schema block with types and fields). This allows an attacker to enumerate the schema (queries, types, and field names such as Query, Country, Continent, Language, etc.), facilitating targeted discovery of functionality and potentially sensitive fields or operations. While introspection itself is an information disclosure issue rather than direct code injection, it increases attack surface and can aid in crafting further attacks (authorization bypass, data exfiltration, or complex queries). Recommend disabling introspection in production or restricting it to authenticated/authorized users, and reviewing exposed fields for sensitive data.", "evidence": "Response body contains GraphQL introspection data: \"data\": { \"__schema\": { \"types\": [ { \"name\": \"Query\", \"fields\": [ ... ] }, { \"name\": \"Country\", \"fields\": [ { \"name\": \"code\" }, { \"name\": \"name\" }, ... ] }, ... ] } }", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "Introspection", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "Response body contains GraphQL introspection data: \"data\": { \"__schema\": { \"types\": [ { \"name\": \"Query\", \"fields\": [ ... ] }, { \"name\": \"Country\", \"fields\": [ { \"name\": \"code\" }, { \"name\": \"name\" }, ... ] }, ... ] } }", "explanation": "The GraphQL endpoint returns full introspection results (the __schema block with types and fields). This allows an attacker to enumerate the schema (queries, types, and field names such as Query, Country, Continent, Language, etc.), facilitating targeted discovery of functionality and potentially sensitive fields or operations. While introspection itself is an information disclosure issue rather than direct code injection, it increases attack surface and can aid in crafting further attacks (authorization bypass, data exfiltration, or complex queries). Recommend disabling introspection in production or restricting it to authenticated/authorized users, and reviewing exposed fields for sensitive data."}}]
